title: OpenFOAM computational fluid dynamics (CFD) solver for magnetohydrodynamic open cycles, applied to the Sakhalin pulsed magnetohydrodynamic generator (PMHDG)
comment: 45 pages, 22 figures, 6 tables, published journal article, peer-reviewed, open access
summary: In the current study, we present a mathematical and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model for simulating open-cycle linear Faraday-type continuous-electrode channels of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) power generators, operating on combustion plasma. The model extends the Favre-averaged Navier-Stokes equations to account for the electric properties of the flowing plasma gas and its reaction to the applied magnetic field. The model takes into account various effects, such as the Lorentz force, turbulence, compressibility, and energy extraction from the plasma, and it adopts an electric potential technique along with the low magnetic Reynolds number (Rem) approximation. The model is numerically implemented using the multiphysics open-source computer programming environment "OpenFOAM," which combines the finite volume method (FVM) and the object-oriented programming (OOP) concept. The capabilities of the model are demonstrated by simulating the supersonic channel of the large-scale pulsed MHD generator (PMHDG) called "Sakhalin", with the aid of collected data and empirical expressions in the literature about its tested operation. Sakhalin was the world's largest PMHDG, with a demonstrated peak electric power output of 510 MW. Sakhalin operated on solid-propellant plasma (SPP), and it had a single supersonic divergent Faraday-type continuous-electrode channel with a length of 4.5 m. We check the validity of the model through comparisons with independent results for the Sakhalin PMHDG. Then, we process our three-dimensional simulation results to provide scalar characteristics of the Sakhalin channel, one-dimensional profiles along the longitudinal centerline, and three-dimensional distributions in the entire channel.

AI.tldr: A CFD model for simulating open-cycle linear Faraday-type MHD power generators is developed using OpenFOAM, validated against the Sakhalin PMHDG (510 MW peak power), and used to analyze 3D flow characteristics.
AI.motivation: To develop a comprehensive mathematical and computational model for simulating MHD power generators that can accurately capture complex plasma flow physics including Lorentz forces, turbulence, compressibility, and energy extraction.
AI.method: Extended Favre-averaged Navier-Stokes equations with electric properties, using electric potential technique and low magnetic Reynolds number approximation, implemented in OpenFOAM with FVM and OOP.
AI.result: Successfully simulated the Sakhalin PMHDG (world's largest at 510 MW peak power), validated against independent results, and generated detailed 3D flow characteristics including scalar parameters, 1D profiles, and 3D distributions.
AI.conclusion: The developed CFD model provides a robust framework for simulating MHD power generators, validated against real-world large-scale PMHDG data, enabling detailed analysis of complex plasma flow physics in these energy conversion systems.

title: Integrated Radiation-Magneto-Hydrodynamic Simulations of Magnetized Burning Plasmas. I. Magnetizing Ignition-Class Designs
summary: Motivated by breakthroughs in inertial confinement fusion (ICF), first achieving ignition conditions in National Ignition Facility (NIF) shot N210808 and then laser energy breakeven in N221204, modeling efforts here investigate the effect of imposed magnetic fields on integrated hohlraum simulations of igniting systems. Previous NIF experiments have shown yield and hotspot temperature to increase in magnetized, gas-filled capsules in line with scalings. In this work, we use the 2D radiation-magnetohydrodynamics code Lasnex with a Livermore ICF common model. Simulations are tuned to closely approximate data from unmagnetized experiments. Investigated here is the effect of imposed axial fields of up to 100 T on the fusion output of high-performing ICF shots, specifically the record BigFoot shot N180128, and HYBRID-E shots N210808 and N221204. The main observed effect is an increase in the hotspot temperature due to magnetic insulation. Namely, electron heat flow is constrained perpendicular to the magnetic field and alpha trajectories transition to gyro-orbits, enhancing energy deposition. In addition, we investigate the impact of applied magnetic fields to future NIF designs, specifically an example Enhanced Yield Capability design with 3 MJ of laser energy as well as a high-\r{ho}R, low implosion velocity "Pushered Single Shell" design. In conclusion, magnetization with field strengths of 5-75 T is found to increase the burn-averaged ion temperature by 50% and the neutron yield by 2-12. Specifically, we see yield enhancement of at least 50% with only a 5-10 T applied magnetic field for N221204, while a 65 T field on N210808 with symmetrization gives an 8 increase in yield. This is all without further design optimization to best take advantage of an applied B field, which promises even greater improvements for designs tailored specifically towards magnetization.

AI.tldr: Applied magnetic fields (5-100 T) in inertial confinement fusion simulations increase hotspot temperature and neutron yield via magnetic insulation and alpha particle confinement, with yield enhancements of 50%+ observed even at modest field strengths.
AI.motivation: Motivated by recent NIF breakthroughs achieving ignition and laser energy breakeven, this research investigates how imposed magnetic fields can enhance fusion performance in ICF systems, building on previous experiments showing yield and temperature increases in magnetized capsules.
AI.method: Using 2D radiation-magnetohydrodynamics code Lasnex with Livermore ICF common model, simulations are tuned to match unmagnetized experimental data. The study examines axial magnetic fields up to 100 T on high-performing ICF shots (N180128, N210808, N221204) and future NIF designs including Enhanced Yield Capability and Pushered Single Shell designs.
AI.result: Magnetic fields of 5-75 T increase burn-averaged ion temperature by 50% and neutron yield by 2-12×. Specifically: 5-10 T field on N221204 gives ≥50% yield enhancement; 65 T field on N210808 with symmetrization gives 8× yield increase. Magnetic insulation constrains electron heat flow perpendicular to field and enhances alpha particle energy deposition.
AI.conclusion: Applied magnetic fields significantly improve ICF performance through magnetic insulation effects, with even modest fields (5-10 T) providing substantial yield enhancements. Future designs specifically optimized for magnetization promise even greater improvements beyond the 2-12× yield increases observed in current simulations.

title: GKFieldFlow: A Spatio-Temporal Neural Surrogate for Nonlinear Gyrokinetic Turbulence
summary:
We present GKFieldFlow, a novel three-dimensional autoregressive deep learning surrogate model for nonlinear gyrokinetic turbulence. Based on the architecture FieldFlow-Net, this model combines a multi-resolution 3D U-Net encoder-decoder that operates on evolving plasma potential fields. A dilated temporal convolutional network (TCN) learns the nonlinear time evolution of latent turbulence features. GKFieldFlow simultaneously (i) predicts ion and electron energy fluxes, and particle flux directly from CGYRO turbulence, and (ii) predicts future potential fields autoregressively with desired spatial resolution. This enables the model to replicate both instantaneous transport and the underlying spatio-temporal dynamics that generate it.
  The architecture is physics-informed in its design: 3D convolutions preserve the anisotropic geometry and phase structure of gyrokinetic fluctuations, while dilated temporal convolutions capture multiscale dynamical couplings such as turbulence and zonal-flow interactions, turbulence decorrelation, and intermittent bursty transport. We provide a complete technical description of the data structure, model components, and rationale behind each architectural choice.
  The model achieves high accuracy across all three transport channels, with multi-horizon inference maintaining robustness. Autoregressive field rollouts preserve the spectral content, phase coherence, and energy distribution of the CGYRO nonlinear state with strong fidelity, and flux predictions remain consistent with CGYRO within a small fractional error. This work presents GKFieldFlow as a data-driven reduced model that can jointly learn turbulence dynamics and transport.

AI.tldr: GKFieldFlow is a 3D autoregressive deep learning surrogate model for gyrokinetic turbulence that predicts transport fluxes and future potential fields while preserving turbulence physics.
AI.motivation: Need for efficient surrogate models to capture complex nonlinear gyrokinetic turbulence dynamics and transport predictions, which are computationally expensive to simulate with traditional gyrokinetic codes like CGYRO.
AI.method: Combines multi-resolution 3D U-Net encoder-decoder for spatial features with dilated temporal convolutional network (TCN) for time evolution. Uses physics-informed architecture with 3D convolutions preserving anisotropic geometry and phase structure, and dilated convolutions capturing multiscale dynamical couplings.
AI.result: Achieves high accuracy across all three transport channels (ion/electron energy fluxes, particle flux). Autoregressive field rollouts preserve spectral content, phase coherence, and energy distribution with strong fidelity. Flux predictions remain consistent with CGYRO within small fractional error.
AI.conclusion: GKFieldFlow serves as an effective data-driven reduced model that can jointly learn turbulence dynamics and transport, enabling efficient prediction of both instantaneous transport and underlying spatio-temporal dynamics.

title: Hölder estimates of weak solutions to chemotaxis systems of fast diffusion type
summary: We study a quasilinear chemotaxis system of singular type, where the diffusion operator is given by $Δu^m$ with $0<m<1$, corresponding to the fast diffusion regime, and where the chemotactic drift is nonlinear. Since Hölder continuity constitutes the optimal regularity class for weak solutions to the porous medium equation, we establish analogous regularity results for bounded solutions of parabolic--parabolic chemotaxis systems in this setting. The proof is based on a refined De Giorgi--Di Benedetto iteration scheme adapted to the coupled structure of the system. These results advance the understanding of the fine regularity properties of chemotaxis models with nonlinear diffusion, and demonstrate that the interplay between singular diffusion and aggregation exhibits a regularizing mechanism consistent with the porous medium paradigm.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes Hölder continuity for bounded solutions to quasilinear chemotaxis systems with fast diffusion (0<m<1) and nonlinear chemotactic drift, extending porous medium equation regularity to coupled chemotaxis systems.
AI.motivation: To understand the fine regularity properties of chemotaxis models with nonlinear diffusion, specifically examining how the interplay between singular diffusion (fast diffusion regime) and aggregation affects solution regularity.
AI.method: A refined De Giorgi-Di Benedetto iteration scheme adapted to the coupled structure of the chemotaxis system, building on techniques from porous medium equation analysis.
AI.result: Establishes Hölder continuity as the optimal regularity class for bounded solutions of parabolic-parabolic chemotaxis systems with fast diffusion (0<m<1), demonstrating that the singular diffusion-aggregation interplay exhibits a regularizing mechanism consistent with porous medium paradigms.
AI.conclusion: The study advances understanding of regularity in chemotaxis models with nonlinear diffusion, showing that fast diffusion combined with chemotactic aggregation produces regularizing effects analogous to those in porous medium equations.

title: Thrust Regulation in a Solid Fuel Ramjet using Dynamic Mode Adaptive Control
comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:2601.01683
summary: This paper presents the application of a novel data-driven adaptive control technique, called dynamic mode adaptive control (DMAC), for regulating thrust in a solid fuel ramjet (SFRJ). A high-fidelity computational model incorporating compressible flow theory and equilibrium chemistry is used to simulate the combustion dynamics. An adaptive tracking controller is designed using the DMAC framework, which leverages dynamic mode decomposition to approximate the local system behavior, followed by a tracking controller synthesized around the identified model. Simulation results demonstrate that DMAC provides an effective and reliable approach for thrust regulation in SFRJs. In addition, a systematic hyperparameter sensitivity study is conducted by varying the tuning parameters over several orders of magnitude. The resulting responses show that the closed-loop performance and tracking error remain stable across wide parameter variations, indicating that DMAC exhibits strong robustness to hyper parameter tuning.

AI.tldr: DMAC (dynamic mode adaptive control) applied to thrust regulation in solid fuel ramjets shows effective performance and strong robustness to hyperparameter tuning.
AI.motivation: Need for effective thrust regulation in solid fuel ramjets (SFRJs) using adaptive control techniques that can handle complex combustion dynamics.
AI.method: DMAC framework uses dynamic mode decomposition to approximate local system behavior, followed by tracking controller synthesis. High-fidelity computational model with compressible flow theory and equilibrium chemistry simulates combustion dynamics.
AI.result: DMAC provides effective and reliable thrust regulation. Systematic hyperparameter sensitivity study shows closed-loop performance remains stable across wide parameter variations, demonstrating strong robustness.
AI.conclusion: DMAC is a promising adaptive control approach for SFRJ thrust regulation with demonstrated effectiveness and robustness to parameter tuning.

title: RONS Generation in Plasma-Activated Saline for Wound Healing
summary: This study explores the physicochemical modifications and antimicrobial potential of plasma activated saline generated by exposing Sodium Chloride and Ringer solution to atmospheric pressure dielectric barrier discharge plasma. Plasma activation produced reactive oxygen and nitrogen species leading to changes in pH, redox potential, conductivity and concentrations of Hydrogen Peroxide, Nitrogen and Nitrous Oxides. Effects of activation time, voltage, and gas composition were analyzed. Antimicrobial activity against Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and E coli was assessed via MIC, CFU reduction and biofilm inhibition tests. Optimal plasma exposure achieved strong microbial inactivation with good biocompatibility. SEM and FTIR confirmed membrane damage, supporting PAS as a safe, nonantibiotic wound irrigation and disinfectant solution.

AI.tldr: Plasma-activated saline shows strong antimicrobial effects against common pathogens through reactive species generation, making it a promising non-antibiotic wound disinfectant.
AI.motivation: To develop a safe, non-antibiotic alternative for wound irrigation and disinfection by leveraging plasma technology to create reactive species in saline solutions.
AI.method: Exposed Sodium Chloride and Ringer solution to atmospheric pressure dielectric barrier discharge plasma, analyzed physicochemical changes (pH, redox potential, conductivity, reactive species), tested antimicrobial activity via MIC, CFU reduction, biofilm inhibition against S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, and E. coli, and used SEM/FTIR for membrane damage analysis.
AI.result: Plasma activation generated reactive oxygen/nitrogen species, changing solution properties. Optimal plasma exposure achieved strong microbial inactivation with good biocompatibility. SEM/FTIR confirmed membrane damage to bacteria.
AI.conclusion: Plasma-activated saline is a safe, effective non-antibiotic wound irrigation and disinfectant solution with demonstrated antimicrobial activity against common pathogens.

title: Travelling Waves in a Mathematical Model for Oncolytic Virotherapy
summary: Oncolytic virotherapy (OVT) is a promising cancer treatment strategy in which engineered viruses selectively infect and destroy tumor cells. Motivated by the biological mechanisms underlying viral spread and tumor invasion into the tissue, we analyze a non-cooperative reaction-diffusion model capturing the invasion of tumor tissue by oncolytic viruses. Using carefully constructed upper and lower solutions together with Schauder's fixed point theorem, we establish the existence of positive travelling-wave solutions. In particular, we identify a minimal wave speed value $\bar c$ such that positive travelling waves exist for all $c \geq \bar c$ . Our analysis also highlights parameter regions where the existence of travelling waves remains ambiguous, suggesting new mathematical questions about the propagation of viral treatments through tumor environments.

AI.tldr: Analysis of traveling wave solutions in a reaction-diffusion model for oncolytic virotherapy, establishing existence of positive traveling waves above a minimal wave speed threshold.
AI.motivation: Oncolytic virotherapy is a promising cancer treatment where engineered viruses selectively target tumor cells. The paper aims to mathematically model and analyze the invasion of tumor tissue by oncolytic viruses using biological mechanisms of viral spread and tumor invasion.
AI.method: The authors use a non-cooperative reaction-diffusion model to capture tumor-virus interactions. They employ carefully constructed upper and lower solutions together with Schauder's fixed point theorem to establish the existence of positive traveling-wave solutions.
AI.result: The analysis identifies a minimal wave speed value $\bar{c}$ such that positive traveling waves exist for all $c \geq \bar{c}$. The work also reveals parameter regions where traveling wave existence remains ambiguous, suggesting new mathematical questions about viral treatment propagation.
AI.conclusion: The study provides rigorous mathematical foundations for understanding oncolytic virus spread through tumor environments, establishing existence conditions for traveling wave solutions while highlighting unresolved mathematical questions about parameter-dependent propagation dynamics.

title: Deep learning parameter estimation and quantum control of single molecule
summary: Coherent control, a central concept in physics and chemistry, has sparked significant interest due to its ability to fine-tune interference effects in atoms and individual molecules for applications ranging from light-harvesting complexes to molecular qubits. However, precise characterization of the system's dissipative dynamics is required for its implementation, especially at high temperature. In a quantum control experiment, this means learning system-bath parameters and driving coupling strengths. Here, we demonstrate how to infer key physical parameters of a single molecule driven by spectrally modulated pulses at room temperature. We develop and compare two computational approaches based on two-photon absorption photoluminescence signals: an optimization-based minimization scheme and a feed-forward neural network. The robustness of our approach highlights the importance of reliable parameter estimation in designing effective coherent control protocols. Our results have direct applications in ultrafast spectroscopy, quantum materials and technology.

AI.tldr: Researchers demonstrate methods to infer physical parameters of single molecules driven by modulated pulses at room temperature using two computational approaches based on two-photon absorption photoluminescence signals.
AI.motivation: Coherent control requires precise characterization of dissipative dynamics, especially at high temperatures, which involves learning system-bath parameters and driving coupling strengths for quantum control experiments.
AI.method: Developed and compared two computational approaches: an optimization-based minimization scheme and a feed-forward neural network, both using two-photon absorption photoluminescence signals from single molecules driven by spectrally modulated pulses at room temperature.
AI.result: Demonstrated successful inference of key physical parameters of single molecules, showing the robustness of their approach for reliable parameter estimation in coherent control protocols.
AI.conclusion: The approach enables effective coherent control at room temperature and has direct applications in ultrafast spectroscopy, quantum materials, and quantum technology.

title: Variational (Energy-Based) Spectral Learning: A Machine Learning Framework for Solving Partial Differential Equations
summary: We introduce variational spectral learning (VSL), a machine learning framework for solving partial differential equations (PDEs) that operates directly in the coefficient space of spectral expansions. VSL offers a principled bridge between variational PDE theory, spectral discretization, and contemporary machine learning practice. The core idea is to recast a given PDE \[ \mathcal{L}u = f \quad \text{in} \quad Q=Ω\times(0,T), \] together with boundary and initial conditions, into differentiable space-time energies built from strong-form least-squares residuals and weak (Galerkin) formulations. The solution is represented as a finite spectral expansion \[ u_N(x,t)=\sum_{n=1}^{N} c_n\,φ_n(x,t), \] where $φ_n$ are tensor-product Chebyshev bases in space and time, with Dirichlet-satisfying spatial modes enforcing homogeneous boundary conditions analytically. This yields a compact linear parameterization in the coefficient vector $\mathbf{c}$, while all PDE complexity is absorbed into the variational energy. We show how to construct strong-form and weak-form space-time functionals, augment them with initial-condition and Tikhonov regularization terms, and minimize the resulting objective with gradient-based optimization. In practice, VSL is implemented in TensorFlow using automatic differentiation and Keras cosine-decay-with-restarts learning-rate schedules, enabling robust optimization of moderately sized coefficient vectors. Numerical experiments on benchmark elliptic and parabolic problems, including one- and two-dimensional Poisson, diffusion, and Burgers-type equations, demonstrate that VSL attains accuracy comparable to classical spectral collocation with Crank-Nicolson time stepping, while providing a differentiable objective suitable for modern optimization tooling.

AI.tldr: VSL is a machine learning framework that solves PDEs using spectral expansions in coefficient space, bridging variational PDE theory with modern ML optimization.
AI.motivation: To create a principled bridge between classical variational PDE theory, spectral discretization methods, and contemporary machine learning practice, enabling PDE solving with modern optimization tools.
AI.method: Represents PDE solutions as finite spectral expansions using tensor-product Chebyshev bases, transforms PDEs into differentiable space-time energies (strong-form least-squares and weak Galerkin formulations), and optimizes coefficient vectors using gradient-based methods with automatic differentiation.
AI.result: VSL achieves accuracy comparable to classical spectral collocation with Crank-Nicolson time stepping on benchmark elliptic and parabolic problems (1D/2D Poisson, diffusion, Burgers-type equations), while providing a differentiable objective suitable for modern optimization.
AI.conclusion: VSL successfully bridges classical PDE theory with modern ML practice, offering an effective spectral learning framework that leverages automatic differentiation and modern optimization tooling for solving PDEs.

title: A First-Principles Closure for Nonlocal Magnetized Transport
summary: A reduced kinetic method (RKM) for describing nonlocal transport in magnetized plasmas is derived from first principles and considered in a 1D3V geometry. Unlike standard nonlocal closures, this RKM uses the Fokker-Planck collision operator, therefore local transport results are naturally reproduced for small Knudsen number. An inhibited peak heat flux and preheat of the conductive heat flux are observed, which are expected from physical arguments and previous kinetic studies. Nonlocal behavior of other transport fluxes, namely the Righi-Leduc, Peltier, Ettingshausen, Nernst, thermal force, friction, cross friction, viscous stress, and gyroviscous stress terms are also demonstrated. Neglecting the nonlinear component of the Fokker-Planck collision operator is justified a posteriori. An especially computationally efficient and analytically simpler version of the RKM is presented.

AI.tldr: A reduced kinetic method (RKM) derived from first principles for nonlocal transport in magnetized plasmas, using Fokker-Planck collisions to recover local transport at small Knudsen numbers, with efficient computational implementation.
AI.motivation: To develop a first-principles kinetic method for nonlocal transport in magnetized plasmas that can naturally reproduce local transport results while capturing complex nonlocal phenomena observed in kinetic studies.
AI.method: Derived a reduced kinetic method (RKM) from first principles in 1D3V geometry using the Fokker-Planck collision operator, with justification for neglecting nonlinear collision components and development of computationally efficient simplified version.
AI.result: Observed inhibited peak heat flux and preheat consistent with physical expectations and previous kinetic studies; demonstrated nonlocal behavior of multiple transport fluxes including Righi-Leduc, Peltier, Ettingshausen, Nernst, thermal force, friction, cross friction, viscous stress, and gyroviscous stress terms.
AI.conclusion: The RKM provides a first-principles approach to nonlocal transport that naturally recovers local transport limits, captures expected nonlocal phenomena, and offers computational efficiency through simplified implementation.

title: Mass splitting in the time-discrete generalized Euler equations and non-Monge solutions in multi-marginal optimal transport
summary: The time-discretized, spatially continuous generalized Euler equations are a prototype example of multi-marginal optimal transport, yet the question whether they exhibit mass-splitting (or equivalently, whether they have solutions that are not of Monge form) has remained open. Here we resolve this question by giving a mass-splitting example in one spatial dimension. Moreover we present a related and very simple fully discrete example of mass-splitting which reveals a transparent underlying mechanism.

AI.tldr: The paper resolves the open question of whether time-discretized generalized Euler equations exhibit mass-splitting by providing a counterexample in 1D, and presents a simple discrete example revealing the underlying mechanism.
AI.motivation: The generalized Euler equations serve as a prototype for multi-marginal optimal transport, but it was unknown whether they exhibit mass-splitting (solutions not of Monge form). This question had remained open.
AI.method: The authors construct a mass-splitting example in one spatial dimension for the time-discretized, spatially continuous generalized Euler equations. They also present a related, very simple fully discrete example that reveals the transparent underlying mechanism.
AI.result: The paper successfully resolves the open question by demonstrating that mass-splitting does occur in these equations. The 1D example proves existence of solutions not of Monge form, and the discrete example clarifies the mechanism behind this phenomenon.
AI.conclusion: Mass-splitting does occur in time-discretized generalized Euler equations, answering a longstanding open question. The simple discrete example provides clear insight into why this happens, advancing understanding of multi-marginal optimal transport.

title: Transformation Journey of Zr-based MOFs: Study on Mechanics and Hydrogen Storage under Doping Regulation
summary: This study delves into the transformation journey of Zr-based Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs), focusing on enhancing their mechanical properties and hydrogen storage capacities through doping regulation. MOFs, a versatile class of crystalline porous materials, have garnered significant attention due to their unique properties and broad potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and sensing. Among them, Zr-based MOFs stand out for their exceptional stability and high surface area. This research systematically investigates six key Zr-based MOFs (UIO-66, UIO-67, UIO-68, MOF-801, MOF-802, and MOF-841) using multiscale computational methods, including molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations, and density functional theory (DFT). The study explores the impact of metal ion substitution (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) on the mechanical and hydrogen storage properties of these MOFs. Our findings reveal that metal ion substitution significantly influences the mechanical stability and hydrogen adsorption capacity of Zr-based MOFs, providing valuable insights for the design and optimization of high-performance MOF materials.

AI.tldr: Metal ion doping in Zr-based MOFs improves mechanical stability and hydrogen storage capacity through computational analysis of six key frameworks.
AI.motivation: Zr-based MOFs have exceptional stability and high surface area but need enhancement of mechanical properties and hydrogen storage capacities for practical applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, and sensing.
AI.method: Multiscale computational methods including molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations, and density functional theory (DFT) were used to systematically investigate six Zr-based MOFs (UIO-66, UIO-67, UIO-68, MOF-801, MOF-802, MOF-841) with metal ion substitution (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn).
AI.result: Metal ion substitution significantly influences both mechanical stability and hydrogen adsorption capacity of Zr-based MOFs, with specific doping effects identified for different metal ions.
AI.conclusion: The study provides valuable insights for designing and optimizing high-performance MOF materials through targeted metal ion doping strategies to enhance mechanical properties and hydrogen storage capabilities.

title: On well-posed energy/entropy stable boundary conditions for the rotating shallow water equations
summary: We derive and analyze well-posed, energy- and entropy-stable boundary conditions (BCs) for the two-dimensional linear and nonlinear rotating shallow water equations (RSWE) in vector invariant form. The focus of the study is on subcritical flows, which are commonly observed in atmospheric, oceanic, and geostrophic flow applications. We consider spatial domains with smooth boundaries and formulate both linear and nonlinear BCs using mass flux, Riemann's invariants, and Bernoulli's potential, ensuring that the resulting initial boundary value problem (IBVP) is provably entropy- and energy-stable. The linear analysis is comprehensive, providing sufficient conditions to establish the existence, uniqueness, and energy stability of solutions to the linear IBVP. For the nonlinear IBVP, which admits more general solutions, our goal is to develop nonlinear BCs that guarantee entropy stability. We introduce the concepts of linear consistency and linear stability for nonlinear IBVPs, demonstrating that if a nonlinear IBVP is both linearly consistent and linearly stable, then, for sufficiently regular initial and boundary data over a finite time interval, a unique smooth solution exists. Both the linear and nonlinear IBVPs can be efficiently solved using high-order accurate numerical methods. By employing high-order summation-by-parts operators to discretize spatial derivatives and implementing weak enforcement of BCs via penalty techniques, we develop provably energy- and entropy-stable numerical schemes on curvilinear meshes. Extensive numerical experiments are presented to verify the accuracy of the methods and to demonstrate the robustness of the proposed BCs and numerical schemes.

AI.tldr: The paper develops well-posed, energy- and entropy-stable boundary conditions for 2D rotating shallow water equations using vector invariant form, with comprehensive linear analysis and nonlinear extensions, plus provably stable numerical schemes.
AI.motivation: Subcritical flows in atmospheric, oceanic, and geostrophic applications require stable boundary conditions for rotating shallow water equations to ensure well-posed initial boundary value problems with proper energy and entropy properties.
AI.method: Derived linear and nonlinear BCs using mass flux, Riemann's invariants, and Bernoulli's potential; established linear consistency and stability concepts; developed numerical schemes using high-order summation-by-parts operators with weak penalty enforcement on curvilinear meshes.
AI.result: Proved existence, uniqueness, and energy stability for linear IBVP; showed nonlinear IBVP with linear consistency/stability yields unique smooth solutions; developed provably stable numerical schemes verified through extensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides comprehensive theoretical framework and practical numerical methods for energy- and entropy-stable boundary conditions in rotating shallow water equations, enabling accurate simulation of subcritical geophysical flows.

title: What Is the Minimum Number of Parameters Required to Represent Solutions of the Grad-Shafranov Equation?
summary: Fast and accurate solutions of the Grad--Shafranov (GS) equation are essential for equilibrium analysis, integrated modeling, and surrogate model construction in magnetic confinement fusion. In this work, we address a fundamental question: what is the minimum number of free parameters required to accurately represent numerical solutions of the GS equation under fixed-boundary conditions? We demonstrate that, for most practical applications, GS equilibria can be represented using only 2--5 free parameters while maintaining relative errors below 5\%. For higher-accuracy requirements, we introduce a unified spectral representation based on the Miller extended harmonic (MXH) expansion in the poloidal direction combined with shifted Chebyshev (Cheb) polynomials in the radial direction. This MXH--Cheb basis exhibits rapid convergence for two-dimensional GS equilibria. For configurations where three geometric moments (shift, elongation, and triangularity) are specified at the last closed flux surface (LCFS), relative errors on the order of $10^{-2}$--$10^{-3}$ can be achieved using as few as 13--20 parameters. In more general cases, including up--down asymmetric equilibria, X-point configurations, and stiff pressure and current profiles (e.g., H-mode pedestals), accuracies beyond this level can be obtained with fewer than 100 parameters. The resulting equilibrium configurations and profile functions are fully analytical, with smooth derivatives of all orders. These results provide a systematic foundation for developing high-fidelity, ultra-fast GS solvers and enable efficient reduced-order and AI-based surrogate modeling of tokamak equilibria.

AI.tldr: GS equilibria can be represented with only 2-5 parameters for most applications (<5% error), and with 13-100 parameters for high-accuracy cases using a unified spectral representation.
AI.motivation: Fast and accurate GS equation solutions are essential for fusion equilibrium analysis, integrated modeling, and surrogate model construction. The paper addresses the fundamental question of minimum parameter requirements for accurate GS equilibrium representation.
AI.method: Introduces a unified spectral representation using Miller extended harmonic (MXH) expansion in poloidal direction combined with shifted Chebyshev polynomials in radial direction (MXH-Cheb basis). This approach provides rapid convergence for 2D GS equilibria.
AI.result: For most applications, GS equilibria can be represented with only 2-5 free parameters (<5% error). For higher accuracy with 3 geometric moments at LCFS, 13-20 parameters achieve 10^-2-10^-3 relative error. For complex cases (asymmetric equilibria, X-points, stiff profiles), <100 parameters achieve high accuracy. Results are fully analytical with smooth derivatives.
AI.conclusion: The findings provide systematic foundation for developing high-fidelity, ultra-fast GS solvers and enable efficient reduced-order and AI-based surrogate modeling of tokamak equilibria in magnetic confinement fusion.

title: New approach for elastic collisions with singular stress functions
summary: A collision of a rubber rod to a hard floor is regarded as a simple example of obstacle problems for elastic material. In this article we have proposed a new mathematical model for the collision phenomenon by applying beam equations with singular stress functions, which is investigated in our recent works. As in the works we have established a mathematical method to deal with the singular stress function. Here, we demonstrate the validity of our modeling through observation to the numerical results. Also, we present existence and uniqueness results of the model given as initial boundary value problems.

AI.tldr: A new mathematical model for rubber rod collision using beam equations with singular stress functions, validated numerically with existence/uniqueness proofs.
AI.motivation: To develop a mathematical model for elastic material obstacle problems, specifically rubber rod collisions with hard floors, using singular stress functions.
AI.method: Apply beam equations with singular stress functions (from recent works) to model collision phenomena, using established mathematical methods to handle singularities.
AI.result: Demonstrated model validity through numerical results observation, and presented existence and uniqueness results for the initial boundary value problems.
AI.conclusion: Proposed model successfully captures rubber rod collision dynamics using singular stress functions, with mathematical rigor established through existence/uniqueness proofs.

title: Data-driven Reduction of Transfer Operators for Particle Clustering Dynamics
summary: We develop an operator-based framework to coarse-grain interacting particle systems that exhibit clustering dynamics. Starting from the particle-based transfer operator, we first construct a sequence of reduced representations: the operator is projected onto concentrations and then further reduced by representing the concentration dynamics on a geometric low-dimensional manifold and an adapted finite-state discretization. The resulting coarse-grained transfer operator is finally estimated from dynamical simulation data by inferring the transition probabilities between the Markov states. Applied to systems with multichromatic and Morse interaction potentials, the reduced model reproduces key features of the clustering process, including transitions between cluster configurations and the emergence of metastable states. Spectral analysis and transition-path analysis of the estimated operator reveal implied time scales and dominant transition pathways, providing an interpretable and efficient description of particle-clustering dynamics.

AI.tldr: Operator-based framework for coarse-graining particle clustering dynamics using transfer operators, manifold reduction, and Markov state modeling to analyze transitions between cluster configurations.
AI.motivation: To develop an interpretable and efficient framework for analyzing complex clustering dynamics in interacting particle systems, which exhibit transitions between cluster configurations and metastable states that are difficult to study directly at the particle level.
AI.method: Start from particle-based transfer operator, project onto concentrations, reduce further using geometric low-dimensional manifold representation and adapted finite-state discretization, then estimate coarse-grained transfer operator from simulation data by inferring transition probabilities between Markov states.
AI.result: The reduced model successfully reproduces key clustering features including transitions between cluster configurations and emergence of metastable states for systems with multichromatic and Morse interaction potentials. Spectral and transition-path analysis reveal implied time scales and dominant transition pathways.
AI.conclusion: The operator-based coarse-graining framework provides an interpretable and efficient description of particle-clustering dynamics, enabling analysis of complex transitions and metastable states that would be difficult to study at the full particle level.

title: GPU-Accelerated Energy-Conserving Methods for the Hyperbolized Serre-Green-Naghdi Equations in 2D
comment: 33 pages, 16 figures. Collin Wittenstein and Vincent Marks contributed equally to this work
summary: We develop energy-conserving numerical methods for a two-dimensional hyperbolic approximation of the Serre-Green-Naghdi equations with variable bathymetry for both periodic and reflecting boundary conditions. The hyperbolic formulation avoids the costly inversion of an elliptic operator present in the classical model. Our schemes combine split forms with summation-by-parts (SBP) operators to construct semidiscretizations that conserve the total water mass and the total energy. We provide analytical proofs of these conservation properties and also verify them numerically. While the framework is general, our implementation focuses on second-order finite-difference SBP operators. The methods are implemented in Julia for CPU and GPU architectures (AMD and NVIDIA) and achieve substantial speedups on modern accelerators. We validate the approach through convergence studies based on solitary-wave and manufactured-solution tests, and by comparisons to analytical, experimental, and existing numerical results. All source code to reproduce our results is available online.

AI.tldr: Energy-conserving numerical methods for 2D hyperbolic approximation of Serre-Green-Naghdi equations with variable bathymetry using SBP operators for mass and energy conservation.
AI.motivation: To develop efficient numerical methods for the Serre-Green-Naghdi equations that avoid costly elliptic operator inversion while maintaining conservation properties for both periodic and reflecting boundary conditions.
AI.method: Combines split forms with summation-by-parts (SBP) operators to create semidiscretizations that conserve total water mass and total energy. Uses second-order finite-difference SBP operators, implemented in Julia for CPU and GPU architectures.
AI.result: Methods conserve total water mass and total energy (proven analytically and verified numerically). Achieves substantial speedups on modern accelerators (AMD/NVIDIA GPUs). Validated through convergence studies using solitary-wave tests, manufactured solutions, and comparisons to analytical/experimental/numerical results.
AI.conclusion: Developed energy-conserving numerical methods for hyperbolic Serre-Green-Naghdi equations that are efficient (avoid elliptic inversion), conserve key properties, work on modern hardware, and are validated against multiple benchmarks. Source code is publicly available.

title: Nutritional and growth enhancement of alfalfa sprouts through cold plasma and UV seed treatments
summary: Employing eco-friendly techniques like cold plasma (CP) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation provides innovative approaches to enhance the sprout quality and productivity of alfalfa. This study explores the effects of CP and UV radiation on the germination, growth, and phytochemical profiles of alfalfa sprouts. CP significantly accelerated germination time, reducing median germination time by 8 hours compared to the control, and enhanced photo synthetic pigments, leading to higher biomass (25.87 mg/sprout fresh weight and 1.45 mg/sprout dry weight). UV treatments, particularly UV-C, increased chlorophyll and total flavonoid content. Overall, CP effectively promotes alfalfa germination and growth, while UV treatments improve specific phytochemicals.

AI.tldr: Cold plasma and UV radiation treatments improve alfalfa sprout quality - CP accelerates germination and increases biomass, while UV boosts phytochemicals like flavonoids.
AI.motivation: To explore eco-friendly techniques (cold plasma and UV radiation) for enhancing sprout quality and productivity of alfalfa, addressing the need for sustainable agricultural methods.
AI.method: Applied cold plasma (CP) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation treatments to alfalfa seeds/sprouts, with UV-C as a specific UV treatment, and measured effects on germination time, growth parameters, photosynthetic pigments, biomass, and phytochemical profiles.
AI.result: CP reduced median germination time by 8 hours, increased fresh weight to 25.87 mg/sprout and dry weight to 1.45 mg/sprout, and enhanced photosynthetic pigments. UV treatments, especially UV-C, increased chlorophyll and total flavonoid content.
AI.conclusion: Cold plasma effectively promotes alfalfa germination and growth, while UV treatments improve specific phytochemicals, offering complementary eco-friendly approaches for enhancing alfalfa sprout quality and productivity.

title: Quasiconvexity in the Riemannian setting
summary: We introduce a notion of quasiconvexity for continuous functions $f$ defined on the vector bundle of linear maps between the tangent spaces of a smooth Riemannian manifold $(M,g)$ and $\mathbb{R}^m$, naturally generalizing the classical Euclidean definition. We prove that this condition characterizes the sequential lower semicontinuity of the associated integral functional \[ F(u, Ω) = \int_Ω f(du) \, dμ\] with respect to the weak$^*$ topology of $W^{1,\infty}(Ω, \mathbb{R}^m)$, for every bounded open subset $Ω\subseteq M$.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a quasiconvexity notion for functions on vector bundles over Riemannian manifolds, characterizing weak* lower semicontinuity of integral functionals in W^{1,∞} spaces.
AI.motivation: To extend classical Euclidean quasiconvexity theory to Riemannian manifolds, enabling analysis of integral functionals in geometric settings where the domain is not flat Euclidean space.
AI.method: Define quasiconvexity for continuous functions on vector bundles of linear maps between tangent spaces of Riemannian manifolds and ℝ^m, then prove this condition characterizes sequential lower semicontinuity of integral functionals.
AI.result: The introduced quasiconvexity condition is necessary and sufficient for sequential lower semicontinuity of the integral functional F(u,Ω) with respect to weak* topology in W^{1,∞}(Ω,ℝ^m) for bounded open subsets Ω⊆M.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully generalizes Euclidean quasiconvexity to Riemannian manifolds, providing a complete characterization of weak* lower semicontinuity for integral functionals in geometric settings.

title: DeepH-pack: A general-purpose neural network package for deep-learning electronic structure calculations
summary: In computational physics and materials science, first-principles methods, particularly density functional theory, have become central tools for electronic structure prediction and materials design. Recently, rapid advances in artificial intelligence (AI) have begun to reshape the research landscape, giving rise to the emerging field of deep-learning electronic structure calculations. Despite numerous pioneering studies, the field remains in its early stages; existing software implementations are often fragmented, lacking unified frameworks and standardized interfaces required for broad community adoption. Here we present DeepH-pack, a comprehensive and unified software package that integrates first-principles calculations with deep learning. By incorporating fundamental physical principles into neural-network design, such as the nearsightedness principle and the equivariance principle, DeepH-pack achieves robust cross-scale and cross-material generalizability. This allows models trained on small-scale structures to generalize to large-scale and previously unseen materials. The toolkit preserves first-principles accuracy while accelerating electronic structure calculations by several orders of magnitude, establishing an efficient and intelligent computational paradigm for large-scale materials simulation, high-throughput materials database construction, and AI-driven materials discovery.

AI.tldr: DeepH-pack is a unified software package that combines first-principles calculations with deep learning for accelerated electronic structure predictions while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: Existing AI-based electronic structure software is fragmented and lacks unified frameworks needed for broad adoption, despite rapid advances in AI reshaping computational physics and materials science.
AI.method: Integrates first-principles calculations with deep learning by incorporating physical principles (nearsightedness and equivariance principles) into neural network design for cross-scale and cross-material generalization.
AI.result: Achieves robust generalizability allowing models trained on small structures to work on large-scale and unseen materials, preserves first-principles accuracy while accelerating calculations by orders of magnitude.
AI.conclusion: Establishes an efficient computational paradigm for large-scale materials simulation, high-throughput database construction, and AI-driven materials discovery through a comprehensive unified software package.

title: A Schrödinger-Based Dispersive Regularization Approach for Numerical Simulation of One-Dimensional Shallow Water Equations
summary:
We propose a novel dispersive regularization framework for the numerical simulation of the one-dimensional shallow water equations (SWE). The classical hyperbolic system is regularized by a third-order dispersive term in the momentum equation, which renders the system equivalent, via the Madelung transform, to a defocusing cubic nonlinear Schrödinger equation with a drift term induced by bottom topography.
  Instead of solving the shallow water equations directly, we solve the associated Schrödinger equation and recover the hydrodynamic variables through a simple postprocessing procedure. This approach transforms the original nonlinear hyperbolic system into a semilinear complex-valued equation, which can be efficiently approximated using a Strang time-splitting method combined with a spectral element discretization in space.
  Numerical experiments demonstrate that, in subcritical regimes without shock formation, the Schrödinger regularization provides an $O(\varepsilon)$ approximation to the classical shallow water solution, where $\varepsilon$ denotes the regularization parameter. Importantly, we observe that this convergence behavior persists even in the presence of moving wetting--drying interfaces, where vacuum states emerge and standard shallow water solvers often encounter difficulties. These results suggest that the Schrödinger-based formulation offers a robust and promising alternative framework for the numerical simulation of shallow water flows with dry states.

AI.tldr: A dispersive regularization framework transforms shallow water equations into a nonlinear Schrödinger equation via Madelung transform, enabling robust numerical simulation even with wetting-drying interfaces.
AI.motivation: Standard shallow water solvers struggle with moving wetting-drying interfaces and vacuum states. The authors seek a more robust numerical framework that can handle these challenging dry states while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Regularize the shallow water equations with a third-order dispersive term, transforming them via Madelung transform into a defocusing cubic nonlinear Schrödinger equation with drift. Solve this Schrödinger equation using Strang time-splitting method with spectral element discretization, then recover hydrodynamic variables through postprocessing.
AI.result: In subcritical regimes without shocks, the Schrödinger regularization provides O(ε) approximation to classical shallow water solutions. Crucially, this convergence persists even with moving wetting-drying interfaces and vacuum states where standard solvers fail.
AI.conclusion: The Schrödinger-based formulation offers a robust and promising alternative framework for numerical simulation of shallow water flows with dry states, overcoming difficulties encountered by traditional shallow water solvers.

title: Spectral Properties and Energy Injection in Mercury's Magnetotail Current Sheet
summary: Mercury's magnetotail hosts a thin and highly dynamic current sheet (CS), where magnetic reconnection and strong fluctuations frequently occur. Here, we statistically analyze magnetic field power spectra across 370 magnetotail CSs observed by MESSENGER. About 20% of the events are quasi-laminar, showing single power-law spectra, whereas 80% are turbulent, exhibiting a spectral break separating inertial and kinetic ranges. A dawn-dusk asymmetry is identified: inertial-range slopes are systematically shallower on the dawnside, whereas kinetic-range slopes are steeper, indicating more developed turbulence there, consistent with the higher occurrence of reconnection-related processes on the dawnside. Component analysis shows that the transverse components, orthogonal to the tail-aligned principal field (BX), display shallow slopes near -1 in the inertial range, suggesting energy injection at ion scales rather than a classical inertial range. These results demonstrate that Mercury's unique plasma environment fundamentally reshapes the initiation of turbulence and the redistribution of energy in the magnetotail.

AI.tldr: Mercury's magnetotail current sheets show 80% turbulent events with spectral breaks, revealing dawn-dusk asymmetry in turbulence development and energy injection at ion scales rather than classical inertial range.
AI.motivation: To understand turbulence characteristics in Mercury's unique magnetotail environment, where thin current sheets frequently experience magnetic reconnection and strong fluctuations, and to investigate how this differs from Earth's magnetosphere.
AI.method: Statistical analysis of magnetic field power spectra across 370 magnetotail current sheets observed by MESSENGER spacecraft, including spectral slope analysis, dawn-dusk asymmetry examination, and component analysis of transverse vs. tail-aligned magnetic fields.
AI.result: 20% of events are quasi-laminar (single power-law), 80% turbulent (spectral breaks). Dawnside shows shallower inertial-range slopes and steeper kinetic-range slopes, indicating more developed turbulence. Transverse components show shallow slopes near -1 in inertial range, suggesting energy injection at ion scales rather than classical inertial range.
AI.conclusion: Mercury's unique plasma environment fundamentally reshapes turbulence initiation and energy redistribution in the magnetotail, with turbulence development linked to reconnection processes and showing distinct characteristics from Earth's magnetosphere.

title: On Liouiville Type Theorem for the 3D Isentropic Navier-Stokes System without D-condition
summary: In this paper, we establish Liouville-type theorems for the steady compressible Navier-Stokes system. Assuming a smooth solution \(u \in L^p(\mathbb{R}^3)\), \(3 \le p \le \frac{9}{2}\), with bounded density, one obtains \(u \equiv0\). This generalizes the result of Li-Yu \cite{Li-Yu} by removing the Dirichlet condition \(\int_{\mathbb{R}^3} |\nabla u|^2 \, dx < \infty\). If \(\frac{9}{2} < p < 6\), Liouville-type theorem holds under the additional oscillation condition for momentum \(ρu \in \dot{B}^{\frac{3}{p} - \frac{3}{2}}_{\infty,\infty}(\mathbb{R}^3)\). For the marginal case \(u \in L^6(\mathbb{R}^3)\), the oscillation condition can be replaced by \(ρu \in BMO^{-1}(\mathbb{R}^3)\). We also present results in Morrey-type spaces: \(u \in \dot{M}^{s,6}(\mathbb{R}^3)\) and \(ρu \in \dot{M}_w^{q,3}(\mathbb{R}^3)\) for \(2 \le s \le 6\) and \(\frac{3}{2} < q \le 3\).

AI.tldr: Liouville-type theorems for steady compressible Navier-Stokes: smooth solutions with bounded density vanish under various integrability conditions, generalizing previous results and extending to Morrey spaces.
AI.motivation: To establish Liouville-type theorems (vanishing results) for steady compressible Navier-Stokes equations, generalizing previous work by Li-Yu and removing restrictive conditions like the Dirichlet energy bound.
AI.method: Analyze smooth solutions in various function spaces (L^p, Morrey spaces) with bounded density conditions. Use different integrability ranges and oscillation conditions for momentum to prove vanishing results.
AI.result: For 3 ≤ p ≤ 9/2: u ≡ 0 without Dirichlet condition. For 9/2 < p < 6: vanishing holds with momentum oscillation condition. For p=6: vanishing with BMO^{-1} condition. Also establish results in Morrey spaces with specific parameter ranges.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes comprehensive Liouville-type theorems for steady compressible Navier-Stokes under various integrability conditions, significantly extending previous results and providing complete characterization across different function spaces.

title: Volumetric locking-free Mixed Virtual Element Methods for Contact Problems
summary: We consider the approximation of the 2D frictionless contact problem in elasticity using the Virtual Element Methods (VEMs). To overcome the volumetric locking phenomenon in the nearly incompressible case, we adopt a mixed displacement/pressure ($u/p$) variational formulation, where pressure is introduced as an independent unknown. We present the VEM discretization and develop a general error analysis, keeping explicit track of the constants involved in the error estimates, thus allowing to consider meshes with "small edges". As examples, we consider two possible VEM schemes: a first-order scheme and a second-order scheme. The numerical results confirm the theoretical predictions, specifically both schemes show: 1) robustness with respect to the volumetric parameter $λ$, thus preventing the occurrence of the volumetric locking phenomenon; 2) good behavior even in the presence of "small edges"; 3) achievement of the expected theoretical convergence rates.

AI.tldr: VEM approximation of 2D frictionless contact in elasticity using mixed u/p formulation to prevent volumetric locking, with error analysis for meshes with small edges and validation of first/second-order schemes.
AI.motivation: To address volumetric locking in nearly incompressible elasticity contact problems and handle meshes with small edges while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Mixed displacement/pressure (u/p) variational formulation with Virtual Element Methods (VEMs), developing general error analysis with explicit constants, applied to first-order and second-order VEM schemes.
AI.result: Numerical results confirm: 1) robustness to volumetric parameter λ (no locking), 2) good performance with small edges, 3) achievement of expected convergence rates for both schemes.
AI.conclusion: The proposed VEM approach with mixed u/p formulation effectively prevents volumetric locking, handles challenging mesh geometries, and achieves theoretical convergence rates for 2D frictionless contact problems.

title: Magnetic reconnection with a 0.1 rate: Effective resistivity in general relativistic magnetohydrodynamics
summary: Relativistic magnetic reconnection is thought to power various multi-wavelength emission signatures from neutron stars and black holes. Relativistic resistive magnetohydrodynamics (RRMHD) offers the simplest model of reconnection. However, a small uniform resistivity underestimates the reconnection rate compared to first-principles kinetic models. By employing an effective resistivity based on kinetic models - which connects the reconnection electric field to the charge-starved current density - we show that RRMHD can reproduce the increased reconnection rate of kinetic models, both in local current sheets and in global black hole magnetospheres.

AI.tldr: RRMHD with kinetic-based effective resistivity reproduces higher reconnection rates matching kinetic models in both local and global astrophysical systems.
AI.motivation: Standard RRMHD with uniform resistivity underestimates reconnection rates compared to kinetic models, limiting its ability to accurately model relativistic reconnection in neutron stars and black holes.
AI.method: Employ an effective resistivity derived from kinetic models that relates reconnection electric field to charge-starved current density, then apply this in RRMHD simulations.
AI.result: RRMHD with kinetic-based effective resistivity successfully reproduces the increased reconnection rates observed in kinetic models, working in both local current sheets and global black hole magnetospheres.
AI.conclusion: By incorporating kinetic-informed effective resistivity, RRMHD becomes a more accurate and computationally efficient tool for modeling relativistic magnetic reconnection in astrophysical systems.

title: Higher order H{ö}lder approximation by solutions of second order elliptic equations
summary: For a given second order elliptic operation $\mathcal{L}$ in a domain $Ω\subset{\mathbb{R}}^\mathbf{N}$, $\mathbf{N}\ $, and a compact set $\mathbf{K}\subsetΩ$, order $\mathbf{N}$-$2$-Ahlfors-David regular, we define the space $\mathcal{H}^{\mathbf{r}+ω}_{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{K})$ of continuous functions $f(x),\, x\in\mathbf{K}$, admitting, for any $δ>0$, a local approximation in the $δ$-neighborhood of any point $x\in\mathbf{K}$, with $δ^{\mathbf{r}}ω(δ)$-error estimate, by solutions of the equation $\mathcal{L} u=0$. For such functions, we prove the existence of a global approximation $v_δ$ on $\mathbf{K}$ with the same order of error estimate, by a solution of the same equation in a $δ$-neighborhood of $\mathbf{K}$. A number of properties of these functions $v_δ$ and their derivatives are established.

AI.tldr: The paper studies approximation properties of functions on compact sets by solutions to elliptic PDEs, establishing local-to-global approximation results with precise error estimates.
AI.motivation: To understand how functions defined on compact sets can be approximated by solutions of elliptic partial differential equations, particularly when the functions admit local approximations with specific error estimates near each point.
AI.method: Define function spaces H^{r+ω}_L(K) of continuous functions admitting local approximations by solutions of L u=0 with δ^r ω(δ)-error estimates. Prove existence of global approximations v_δ on K with same error order by solutions in δ-neighborhood of K. Establish properties of v_δ and their derivatives.
AI.result: Existence of global approximations v_δ with same error estimates as local approximations, plus various properties of these approximating functions and their derivatives.
AI.conclusion: Functions admitting local approximations by solutions of elliptic equations can be globally approximated with the same error rates, establishing important connections between local and global approximation properties in elliptic PDE theory.

title: Flow Matching and Diffusion Models via PointNet for Generating Fluid Fields on Irregular Geometries
summary: We present two novel generative geometric deep learning frameworks, termed Flow Matching PointNet and Diffusion PointNet, for predicting fluid flow variables on irregular geometries by incorporating PointNet into flow matching and diffusion models, respectively. In these frameworks, a reverse generative process reconstructs physical fields from standard Gaussian noise conditioned on unseen geometries. The proposed approaches operate directly on point-cloud representations of computational domains (e.g., grid vertices of finite-volume meshes) and therefore avoid the limitations of pixelation used to project geometries onto uniform lattices. In contrast to graph neural network-based diffusion models, Flow Matching PointNet and Diffusion PointNet do not exhibit high-frequency noise artifacts in the predicted fields. Moreover, unlike such approaches, which require auxiliary intermediate networks to condition geometry, the proposed frameworks rely solely on PointNet, resulting in a simple and unified architecture. The performance of the proposed frameworks is evaluated on steady incompressible flow past a cylinder, using a geometric dataset constructed by varying the cylinder's cross-sectional shape and orientation across samples. The results demonstrate that Flow Matching PointNet and Diffusion PointNet achieve more accurate predictions of velocity and pressure fields, as well as lift and drag forces, and exhibit greater robustness to incomplete geometries compared to a vanilla PointNet with the same number of trainable parameters.

AI.tldr: Two generative geometric deep learning frameworks (Flow Matching PointNet and Diffusion PointNet) for predicting fluid flow variables on irregular geometries using point-cloud representations, outperforming vanilla PointNet in accuracy and robustness.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of pixelation-based methods and graph neural network-based diffusion models that require auxiliary networks and exhibit noise artifacts when predicting fluid flow on irregular geometries.
AI.method: Incorporates PointNet into flow matching and diffusion models to create reverse generative processes that reconstruct physical fields from Gaussian noise conditioned on unseen geometries, operating directly on point-cloud representations without pixelation.
AI.result: Both frameworks achieve more accurate predictions of velocity/pressure fields and lift/drag forces, show greater robustness to incomplete geometries, and avoid high-frequency noise artifacts compared to vanilla PointNet with same parameters.
AI.conclusion: The proposed frameworks provide simple, unified architectures for accurate fluid flow prediction on irregular geometries using point-cloud representations, outperforming existing approaches while avoiding their limitations.

title: A Derivative-Free Saddle-search Algorithm With Linear Convergence Rate
summary: We propose a derivative-free saddle-search algorithm designed to locate transition states using only function evaluations. The algorithm employs a nested architecture consisting of an inner eigenvector search and an outer saddle-point search. Through rigorous numerical analysis, we prove the almost sure convergence of the inner step under suitable assumptions. Furthermore, we establish the convergence of the outer search using a decaying step size, while demonstrating linear convergence under constant step size and boundedness conditions. Numerical experiments are provided to validate our theoretical results and demonstrate the algorithm's practical applicability.

AI.tldr: A derivative-free algorithm for finding transition states using only function evaluations, with proven convergence guarantees and numerical validation.
AI.motivation: To develop a practical method for locating transition states (saddle points) in complex systems without requiring gradient information, which is often computationally expensive or unavailable in many applications.
AI.method: A nested architecture with inner eigenvector search and outer saddle-point search, using only function evaluations (no derivatives). The algorithm employs decaying step sizes for convergence and can achieve linear convergence with constant step sizes under boundedness conditions.
AI.result: Theoretical proofs show almost sure convergence of the inner step and convergence of the outer search with decaying step size. Linear convergence is established for constant step sizes with boundedness. Numerical experiments validate the theoretical results and demonstrate practical applicability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed derivative-free saddle-search algorithm provides a theoretically sound and practically useful approach for locating transition states without gradient information, with proven convergence properties and validated performance.

title: Global Hölder Solvability of parabolic equations on domains with capacity density conditions
summary: We investigate the Cauchy-Dirichlet problem for linear parabolic equations in divergence form. Under mild assumptions on the source term and the domain, we prove the existence of globally Hölder continuous solutions. Notably, our results accommodate data exhibiting singularities nearly as critical as the inverse square of the distance from the boundary.

AI.tldr: Existence of globally Hölder continuous solutions for linear parabolic equations with nearly critical boundary singularities
AI.motivation: To establish existence results for parabolic equations with data having singularities near the boundary, specifically singularities almost as strong as the inverse square of distance from boundary
AI.method: Analysis of Cauchy-Dirichlet problem for linear parabolic equations in divergence form under mild assumptions on source term and domain
AI.result: Proved existence of globally Hölder continuous solutions that can accommodate data with singularities nearly as critical as the inverse square of distance from boundary
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes robust existence theory for parabolic equations with boundary-singular data, extending classical results to nearly optimal singularity levels

title: Open-Source Coil Matching Toolbox for Magnetic Stimulation and Other Electromagnetics (COMATOSE)
summary: The coil in transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) determines the spatial shape of the electromagnetic field in the head, which structures are concurrently activated, and how focal stimulation is. Most of the readily available coils have been designed intuitively instead of systematic mathematical-physical optimization as there were no methods available at the time. Previous research however demonstrated that these coils are far from optimum, e.g., for pulse energy or efficiency, and leave substantial room for lots of improvements. Techniques for rigorous mathematical optimization have been developed but are only available to very few groups worldwide. This paper presents an open-source toolbox, COMATOSE, to change that situation and make these methods available to a wider community. It incorporates the fundamental formalisms and offers vector space decomposition as well as base mapping as an explicit forward method, which is computationally less demanding than iterative computational optimization but can also form the initial solution for a subsequent optimization run if desired.

AI.tldr: COMATOSE is an open-source toolbox that makes mathematical optimization methods for TMS coil design accessible to a wider community, offering computationally efficient forward methods and optimization capabilities.
AI.motivation: Current TMS coils are designed intuitively rather than through systematic optimization, leaving substantial room for improvement in pulse energy and efficiency. Existing optimization techniques are only available to very few research groups worldwide.
AI.method: COMATOSE incorporates fundamental formalisms and offers vector space decomposition plus base mapping as an explicit forward method. This approach is computationally less demanding than iterative optimization but can also serve as an initial solution for subsequent optimization runs.
AI.result: The paper presents an open-source toolbox that democratizes access to mathematical optimization methods for TMS coil design, making these advanced techniques available to a broader research community.
AI.conclusion: COMATOSE addresses the accessibility gap in TMS coil optimization, enabling more researchers to systematically design improved coils rather than relying on intuitive approaches, potentially leading to better stimulation outcomes.

title: Stability and error estimates of a linear and partitioned finite element method approximating nonlinear fluid-structure interactions
summary: We propose and analyze a linear and partitioned finite element method for fluid-shell interactions under the arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) framework. We adopt the P1-bubble/P1/P1 elements for the fluid velocity, pressure, and structure velocity, respectively. We show the stability and error estimates of the scheme without assuming infinitesimal structural deformation nor neglecting fluid convection effects. The theoretical convergence rate is further corroborated by numerical experiments.

AI.tldr: A linear partitioned finite element method for fluid-shell interactions using ALE framework with P1-bubble/P1/P1 elements, providing stability and error estimates without small deformation assumptions or neglecting convection effects.
AI.motivation: To develop a robust numerical method for fluid-shell interaction problems that can handle realistic scenarios without requiring restrictive assumptions like infinitesimal structural deformations or neglecting important fluid convection effects.
AI.method: Linear partitioned finite element method using arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) framework with P1-bubble elements for fluid velocity, P1 elements for pressure, and P1 elements for structure velocity. The method is partitioned (separate solvers for fluid and structure) and linear.
AI.result: The scheme demonstrates stability and provides error estimates without requiring infinitesimal structural deformation assumptions or neglecting fluid convection effects. Numerical experiments confirm the theoretical convergence rate.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides a reliable and theoretically sound approach for fluid-shell interaction problems, capable of handling realistic scenarios with proven stability and convergence properties.

title: The W-Operator: A Volterra Fractional Time Operator with Non-Bernstein Symbol
comment: 27 pages, 3 figures. Submitted to Fractional Calculus and Applied Analysis (FCAA)
summary: We introduce a new two-parameter fractional time operator with Volterra structure, denoted by the W-operator, defined through a generalized Laplace symbol. The operator preserves the Caputo-type high-frequency behavior while allowing a controlled modification of the low-frequency regime through an additional parameter, leading to regularized memory effects. We develop a complete symbolic and Volterra theory, including explicit Prabhakar-type kernels, a left-inverse Volterra integral, and a fractional fundamental theorem of calculus. We show that the natural factorization of the Laplace symbol does not fit the classical Bernstein product mechanism and that the symbol is not a Bernstein function in general. Despite this non-Bernstein character, we establish well-posedness of abstract fractional Cauchy problems with sectorial generators by resolvent estimates and Laplace inversion, yielding a W-resolvent family with temporal regularity and smoothing properties. As an illustration, we apply the theory to a W-fractional diffusion model and discuss the influence of the modulation parameter on the relaxation of spectral modes.

AI.tldr: Introduces a new two-parameter fractional time operator (W-operator) with Volterra structure that modifies low-frequency behavior while preserving Caputo-type high-frequency characteristics, enabling regularized memory effects.
AI.motivation: To develop a fractional time operator that allows controlled modification of low-frequency regime while preserving desirable high-frequency properties of Caputo-type operators, creating more flexible memory effects for modeling applications.
AI.method: Defines W-operator through generalized Laplace symbol, develops symbolic and Volterra theory including Prabhakar-type kernels, left-inverse Volterra integral, and fractional fundamental theorem of calculus. Analyzes non-Bernstein character and establishes well-posedness of abstract fractional Cauchy problems using resolvent estimates and Laplace inversion.
AI.result: Complete theoretical framework for W-operator, showing it doesn't fit classical Bernstein product mechanism and isn't a Bernstein function in general. Establishes well-posedness of fractional Cauchy problems with sectorial generators, yielding W-resolvent family with temporal regularity and smoothing properties.
AI.conclusion: The W-operator provides a flexible two-parameter fractional time framework with controlled memory regularization, applicable to diffusion models where modulation parameter influences spectral mode relaxation, offering new modeling capabilities beyond classical fractional operators.

title: A Fourth-Order Cut-cell Multigrid Method for Generic Elliptic Equations on Arbitrary Domains
summary: To numerically solve a generic elliptic equation on two-dimensional domains with rectangular Cartesian grids, we propose a cut-cell geometric multigrid method that features (1) general algorithmic steps that apply to all forms of elliptic equations and all types of boundary conditions, (2) the versatility of handling both regular and irregular domains with arbitrarily complex topology and geometry, (3) the fourth-order accuracy even at the presence of ${\cal C}^1$ discontinuities on the domain boundary, and (4) the optimal complexity of $O(h^{-2})$. Test results demonstrate the generality, accuracy, efficiency, robustness, and excellent conditioning of the proposed method.

AI.tldr: A cut-cell geometric multigrid method for solving elliptic equations on 2D domains with rectangular grids, achieving fourth-order accuracy and optimal O(h⁻²) complexity.
AI.motivation: To develop a general-purpose numerical solver for elliptic equations that can handle complex domains and boundary conditions with high accuracy and efficiency.
AI.method: Cut-cell geometric multigrid method using rectangular Cartesian grids, designed to work with arbitrary domain geometries and all types of boundary conditions.
AI.result: The method achieves fourth-order accuracy even with C¹ discontinuities on domain boundaries, maintains optimal O(h⁻²) complexity, and demonstrates excellent conditioning.
AI.conclusion: The proposed cut-cell geometric multigrid method is general, accurate, efficient, robust, and well-conditioned for solving elliptic equations on complex 2D domains.

title: Rational-Kernel Fractional Evolution Equations with Almost Sectorial Operators: A Resolvent Framework Unifying ABC and W Dynamics
summary: We study fractional evolution equations driven by rational-kernel time operators with non-singular memory, including the Atangana-Baleanu-Caputo operator and a generalized W-operator. These operators are characterized by Laplace symbols that do not necessarily belong to the classical Bernstein class. The analysis is carried out in the framework of almost sectorial operators, which allows resolvent estimates beyond standard analytic semigroup theory. Existence, uniqueness, and temporal regularity of mild solutions are established by Laplace transform techniques and contour integration, leading to the construction of associated resolvent families. A unified resolvent framework is developed, enabling a precise comparison between ABC and W dynamics and clarifying the influence of rational memory kernels on decay and smoothing properties.
