Several examples, including fractional diffusion-type equations, illustrate the abstract theory and highlight the impact of non-singular memory on long-time behavior.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes fractional evolution equations with rational-kernel time operators (ABC and generalized W-operators) using almost sectorial operators framework, establishing existence, uniqueness, regularity, and resolvent families.
AI.motivation: To study fractional evolution equations with non-singular memory kernels (ABC and W-operators) that have Laplace symbols outside classical Bernstein class, requiring analysis beyond standard analytic semigroup theory.
AI.method: Uses almost sectorial operators framework with Laplace transform techniques and contour integration to construct resolvent families and analyze mild solutions.
AI.result: Establishes existence, uniqueness, and temporal regularity of mild solutions; develops unified resolvent framework for comparing ABC and W dynamics; clarifies influence of rational memory kernels on decay and smoothing properties.
AI.conclusion: Provides comprehensive analysis of fractional evolution equations with rational-kernel operators, demonstrating impact of non-singular memory on long-time behavior through examples including fractional diffusion-type equations.

title: Mathematical aspects of registration methods in bounded domains
summary: Registration methods in bounded domains have received significant attention in the model reduction literature, as a valuable tool for nonlinear approximation. The aim of this work is to provide a concise yet complete overview of relevant results for registration methods in $n$-dimensional domains, from the perspective of parametric model reduction. We present a thorough analysis of two classes of methods, vector flows and compositional maps: we discuss the enforcement of the bijectivity constraint and we comment on the approximation properties of the two methods, for Lipschitz $n$-dimensional domains.

AI.tldr: Overview of registration methods for parametric model reduction in n-dimensional domains, focusing on vector flows and compositional maps, with analysis of bijectivity constraints and approximation properties.
AI.motivation: Registration methods in bounded domains are important for nonlinear approximation in model reduction, but need comprehensive analysis from parametric model reduction perspective.
AI.method: Analyzes two classes of registration methods: vector flows and compositional maps. Discusses enforcement of bijectivity constraint and examines approximation properties for Lipschitz n-dimensional domains.
AI.result: Provides concise yet complete overview of relevant results for registration methods in n-dimensional domains from parametric model reduction perspective.
AI.conclusion: Registration methods are valuable tools for nonlinear approximation in model reduction, with vector flows and compositional maps offering different approaches that require careful consideration of bijectivity and approximation properties.

title: Inhomogeneous nonlinear Schrödinger equations with competing singular nonlinearities
summary: We study nonlinear elliptic equations arising as stationary states of inhomogeneous nonlinear Schrödinger equations with competing singular nonlinearities. Working in a weighted Sobolev space that combines the homogeneous Sobolev space with a weighted Lebesgue term, we establish continuous and compact embeddings of Caffarelli--Kohn--Nirenberg type. These embeddings, together with a model that displays a natural scaling, allow us to apply the abstract critical point framework of Mercuri and Perera (2025), yielding a sequence of nonlinear eigenvalues for the associated problem. This scaling property leads to a classification of weighted power-type nonlinearities into subscaled, scaled, and superscaled regimes. Within this variational setting, we obtain broad existence and multiplicity results for equations driven by sums of weighted power nonlinearities, covering superscaled, scaled, and subscaled interactions, both in the subcritical and critical cases. We also provide a nonexistence result as a consequence of a Pohozaev-type identity. Finally, in the radial setting we employ improved radial CKN inequalities to enlarge the admissible embedding ranges. This yields strengthened radial versions of all our main results, including two-dimensional configurations with more singular weights, where no compact embeddings are available in the nonradial case.

AI.tldr: The paper studies nonlinear elliptic equations from inhomogeneous nonlinear Schrödinger equations with competing singular nonlinearities, establishing existence and multiplicity results for nonlinear eigenvalues using variational methods and Caffarelli-Kohn-Nirenberg embeddings.
AI.motivation: To analyze stationary states of inhomogeneous nonlinear Schrödinger equations with competing singular nonlinearities, which arise in various physical contexts and present mathematical challenges due to singular weights and competing nonlinearities.
AI.method: Uses weighted Sobolev spaces combining homogeneous Sobolev spaces with weighted Lebesgue terms, establishes Caffarelli-Kohn-Nirenberg type embeddings, applies Mercuri-Perera critical point framework (2025) with natural scaling model, and employs Pohozaev-type identities and improved radial CKN inequalities.
AI.result: Obtains existence and multiplicity results for nonlinear eigenvalues in superscaled, scaled, and subscaled regimes (subcritical and critical cases), provides nonexistence result via Pohozaev identity, and strengthens results in radial setting with enlarged embedding ranges including 2D configurations with singular weights.
AI.conclusion: The variational framework successfully handles competing singular nonlinearities, with scaling classification providing comprehensive existence theory, and radial analysis extends results to more singular cases where nonradial compact embeddings fail.

title: Pretrain Finite Element Method: A Pretraining and Warm-start Framework for PDEs via Physics-Informed Neural Operators
summary: We propose a Pretrained Finite Element Method (PFEM),a physics driven framework that bridges the efficiency of neural operator learning with the accuracy and robustness of classical finite element methods (FEM). PFEM consists of a physics informed pretraining stage and an optional finetuning stage. In the pretraining stage, a neural operator based on the Transolver architecture is trained solely from governing partial differential equations, without relying on labeled solution data. The model operates directly on unstructured point clouds, jointly encoding geometric information, material properties, and boundary conditions, and produces physically consistent initial solutions with extremely high computational efficiency. PDE constraints are enforced through explicit finite element, based differentiation, avoiding the overhead associated with automatic differentiation. In the fine-tuning stage, the pretrained prediction is used as an initial guess for conventional FEM solvers, preserving their accuracy, convergence guarantees, and extrapolation capability while substantially reducing the number of iterations required to reach a prescribed tolerance. PFEM is validated on a broad range of benchmark problems, including linear elasticity and nonlinear hyperelasticity with complex geometries, heterogeneous materials, and arbitrary boundary conditions. Numerical results demonstrate strong generalization in the pretraining stage with relative errors on the order of 1\%, and speedups of up to one order of magnitude in the fine-tuning stage compared to FEM with zero initial guesses.

AI.tldr: PFEM combines neural operator efficiency with FEM accuracy via physics-informed pretraining on PDEs without labeled data, followed by optional fine-tuning that uses neural predictions as initial guesses for FEM solvers, achieving 1% errors and 10x speedups.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between efficient neural operator learning and accurate/robust classical finite element methods (FEM) by leveraging the strengths of both approaches while overcoming their respective limitations.
AI.method: Two-stage framework: 1) Physics-informed pretraining using Transolver neural operator trained solely from governing PDEs on unstructured point clouds, encoding geometry, materials, and boundary conditions with explicit finite element differentiation; 2) Optional fine-tuning where pretrained predictions serve as initial guesses for conventional FEM solvers.
AI.result: Demonstrated strong generalization in pretraining with ~1% relative errors on linear elasticity and nonlinear hyperelasticity problems with complex geometries, heterogeneous materials, and arbitrary boundary conditions; achieved up to 10x speedups in fine-tuning stage compared to FEM with zero initial guesses.
AI.conclusion: PFEM successfully combines neural operator efficiency with FEM accuracy, providing physically consistent initial solutions without labeled data, preserving FEM convergence guarantees while substantially reducing computational iterations, offering a practical framework for engineering applications.

title: Existence and concentration of ground state solutions for an exponentially critical Choquard equation involving mixed local-nonlocal operators
summary: We study the Choquard equation involving mixed local and nonlocal operators \[-\varepsilon^{2}Δu+\varepsilon^{2s}(-Δ)^{s}u+V(x)u=\varepsilon^{μ-2}\left(\frac{1}{|x|^μ}*F(u)\right)f(u)\quad \text{in }\R^{2},\] where \(\varepsilon>0\), \(s\in(0,1)\), \(0<μ<2\), \(f\) has Trudinger--Moser critical exponential growth, and \(F(t)=\int_{0}^{t}f(τ)\,dτ\). By variational methods, combined with the Trudinger--Moser inequality and compactness arguments adapted to the critical growth and the nonlocal interaction term, we prove the existence of ground state solutions and describe their concentration behavior as \(\varepsilon\to0^{+}\).

AI.tldr: Existence and concentration of ground state solutions for Choquard equation with mixed local-nonlocal operators and Trudinger-Moser critical growth in 2D.
AI.motivation: Study the Choquard equation with mixed local and nonlocal operators in 2D, which combines classical Laplacian with fractional Laplacian, featuring critical exponential growth via Trudinger-Moser inequality and nonlocal convolution interaction.
AI.method: Variational methods combined with Trudinger-Moser inequality and compactness arguments adapted to handle critical exponential growth and nonlocal interaction term.
AI.result: Proved existence of ground state solutions and described their concentration behavior as ε→0⁺.
AI.conclusion: Successfully established existence and concentration properties for solutions to this challenging mixed operator equation with critical growth in 2D.

title: Stability, convergence, and geometric properties of second-order-in-time space-time discretizations for linear and semilinear wave equations
summary: We revisit second-order-in-time space-time discretizations of the linear and semilinear wave equations by establishing precise equivalences with first-order-in-time formulations. Focusing on schemes using continuous piecewise-polynomial trial functions in time, we analyze their stability, convergence, and geometric properties. We consider first a weak space-time formulation with test functions projected onto discontinuous polynomials of one degree lower in time, showing that it is equivalent to the scheme proposed in [French, Peterson 1996] in the linear case, and extended in [Karakashian, Makridakis 2005] to the semilinear case. In particular, this equivalence shows that this method conserves energy at mesh nodes but is not symplectic. We then introduce two symplectic variants, obtained through Gauss-Legendre and Gauss-Lobatto quadratures in time, and show that they correspond to specific Runge-Kutta time integrators. These connections clarify the geometric structure of the space-time methods considered.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes equivalences between second-order-in-time and first-order-in-time space-time discretizations for wave equations, analyzing stability, convergence, and geometric properties of continuous piecewise-polynomial methods.
AI.motivation: To clarify the relationships between different space-time discretization approaches for wave equations, particularly understanding the geometric properties (energy conservation, symplecticity) of these methods and their connections to established time integration schemes.
AI.method: Analyzes weak space-time formulations using continuous piecewise-polynomial trial functions with test functions projected onto discontinuous polynomials of one degree lower. Establishes equivalences with existing methods, then introduces symplectic variants using Gauss-Legendre and Gauss-Lobatto quadratures in time.
AI.result: Shows equivalence between the analyzed method and schemes from French & Peterson (1996) and Karakashian & Makridakis (2005), revealing energy conservation at mesh nodes but lack of symplecticity. Demonstrates that symplectic variants correspond to specific Runge-Kutta time integrators, clarifying geometric structure.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a unified framework connecting different space-time discretization approaches for wave equations, clarifying their geometric properties and relationships to classical time integration methods, which aids in understanding and selecting appropriate numerical schemes.

title: Effect of Electric Charge on Biotherapeutic Transport, Binding and Absorption: A Computational Study
summary: This study explores the effects of electric charge on the dynamics of drug transport and absorption in subcutaneous injections of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). We develop a novel mathematical and computational model, based on the Nernst-Planck equations and porous media flow theory, to investigate the complex interactions between mAbs and charged species in subcutaneous tissue. The model enables us to study short-term transport dynamics and long-term binding and absorption for two mAbs with different electric properties. We examine the influence of buffer pH, body mass index, injection depth, and formulation concentration on drug distribution and compare our numerical results with experimental data from the literature.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a mathematical model to study how electric charge affects monoclonal antibody transport and absorption in subcutaneous injections, examining factors like pH, BMI, injection depth, and concentration.
AI.motivation: To understand the complex effects of electric charge on monoclonal antibody transport and absorption in subcutaneous tissue, which is important for optimizing drug delivery and therapeutic outcomes.
AI.method: Developed a novel mathematical and computational model based on Nernst-Planck equations and porous media flow theory to study interactions between mAbs and charged species in subcutaneous tissue.
AI.result: The model enabled investigation of short-term transport dynamics and long-term binding/absorption for mAbs with different electric properties, examining effects of buffer pH, BMI, injection depth, and formulation concentration.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a computational framework to analyze electric charge effects on subcutaneous mAb delivery, with numerical results compared to experimental literature data to validate the approach.

title: A Kirchhoff equation with infinite conservation laws
summary: We show here that the quasilinear Kirchhoff-Pokhozhaev equation $$u_{tt}-\big(a\int_{\mathbb{R}^n} |\nabla u |^2 dx + b \big)^{-2} Δu = 0,$$ with $a\neq0$, admits conservation laws of all orders.

AI.tldr: The quasilinear Kirchhoff-Pokhozhaev equation admits conservation laws of all orders when a≠0.
AI.motivation: To investigate the conservation properties of the quasilinear Kirchhoff-Pokhozhaev equation, which is a nonlinear wave equation with nonlocal term involving the spatial gradient.
AI.method: Mathematical analysis of the quasilinear Kirchhoff-Pokhozhaev equation, likely using techniques from partial differential equations and conservation law theory.
AI.result: The equation admits conservation laws of all orders when the parameter a is nonzero.
AI.conclusion: The quasilinear Kirchhoff-Pokhozhaev equation possesses rich conservation structure with infinitely many conservation laws when a≠0.

title: On the monotonicity of the entropy production in the Landau-Maxwell equation
summary: We study the homogeneous Landau equation with Maxwell molecules and prove that the entropy production is non-increasing provided the directional temperatures are well-distributed and the solution admits a moment of order $\ell$, for some $\ell$ arbitrarily close to $2$. It implies that for an initial condition with finite moment of order $\ell$, the entropy production is guaranteed to be non-increasing after a certain time, that we explicitly compute. This is the first partial answer to a conjecture made by Henry P. McKean in 1966 on the sign of the time-derivatives of the entropy. We also obtain algebraic decay estimates for the entropy production for large time; as well as a short-time estimate without moment assumptions.

AI.tldr: The paper proves that entropy production in the homogeneous Landau equation with Maxwell molecules is non-increasing under certain conditions, providing the first partial answer to McKean's 1966 conjecture.
AI.motivation: To address Henry P. McKean's 1966 conjecture about the sign of time-derivatives of entropy in the Landau equation, which has remained open for decades.
AI.method: Study the homogeneous Landau equation with Maxwell molecules, analyze entropy production under conditions of well-distributed directional temperatures and existence of moments of order ℓ (arbitrarily close to 2).
AI.result: Proved entropy production is non-increasing under specified conditions; for initial conditions with finite ℓ-moment, entropy production becomes non-increasing after an explicitly computable time; obtained algebraic decay estimates for large time and short-time estimates without moment assumptions.
AI.conclusion: Provides the first partial resolution to McKean's 1966 conjecture, establishing conditions under which entropy production is non-increasing and offering explicit time estimates for this behavior.

title: Freely floating cylinder on a 3D fluid governed by the Boussinesq equations in the axisymmetric without swirl case
summary: This paper deals with the interactions of waves governed by a non-linear dispersive Boussinesq type system with the vertical displacement of a cylindrical floating structure in an axisymmetric without swirl situation. The Boussinesq regime is a good approximation of free surface Euler's equations when the non-linear parameter and the shallowness parameter are small. The vertical motion of the floating body is governed by the Newton equation. The full coupled wave-structure interaction problem under consideration is reduced to a boundary problem. The boundary condition satisfied by the discharge is given in terms of the vertical displacement of the floating cylinder. The latter is calculated using an ODE, which requires knowledge of the trace of the surface elevation and its second-time derivative. We use the dispersion in order to exhibit a hidden second order ODE on the trace of the surface elevation. This finally allows us to rewrite the waves-structure interaction problem as a system of non-local conservative PDEs plus bounded radial terms with a dispersive boundary layer, combined with an ODE at the boundary. This is what we call the Augmented formulation. Afterwards we showed that this formulation is well-posed with two different methods. Finally, we study the return to equilibrium situation in the linear regime. In particular, we improved previous results on the explicit time decay. We showed that the center mass of the floating body cannot converge to its equilibrium faster than $\mathcal{O}(t^{-1/2})$ in 2D without viscosity and faster than $\mathcal{O}(t^{-3/2})$ with viscosity.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes wave-structure interactions between nonlinear dispersive Boussinesq waves and a floating cylindrical body, developing an augmented formulation and studying well-posedness and decay rates.
AI.motivation: To understand the complex interactions between nonlinear dispersive water waves and floating structures, particularly in the Boussinesq regime which approximates Euler's equations for small nonlinearity and shallowness parameters.
AI.method: Reduced the coupled wave-structure problem to a boundary problem, used dispersion to derive a hidden second-order ODE for surface elevation, and developed an "Augmented formulation" combining non-local conservative PDEs with an ODE at the boundary.
AI.result: Proved well-posedness of the augmented formulation using two different methods, and established explicit time decay rates for the return to equilibrium: O(t^{-1/2}) in 2D without viscosity and O(t^{-3/2}) with viscosity.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully develops a mathematical framework for wave-structure interactions, demonstrates its well-posedness, and provides improved decay rate estimates for floating body dynamics in both inviscid and viscous regimes.

title: Forward self-similar solutions to the 2D Navier--Stokes equations
summary: We construct self-similar solutions to the 2D Navier--Stokes equations evolving from arbitrarily large $-1$--homogeneous initial data and present numerical evidence for their non-uniqueness.

AI.tldr: Self-similar solutions to 2D Navier-Stokes equations from large homogeneous initial data, with evidence of non-uniqueness.
AI.motivation: To investigate existence and uniqueness properties of self-similar solutions to 2D Navier-Stokes equations, particularly from large homogeneous initial data where uniqueness questions arise.
AI.method: Construct self-similar solutions analytically and provide numerical evidence for non-uniqueness through computational analysis.
AI.result: Successfully constructed self-similar solutions from arbitrarily large -1-homogeneous initial data and found numerical evidence suggesting these solutions are not unique.
AI.conclusion: The existence of self-similar solutions from large homogeneous data is established, and non-uniqueness is strongly suggested by numerical evidence, challenging uniqueness assumptions for such solutions.

title: Subprincipal Controlled Quasimodes and Spectral Instability
summary: Here we explore, in a series of articles, semiclassical quasimodes u(h,b), approximative solutions P(h)u(h,b)\sim 0, depending on $0<h<1$, and on b, the subprincipal symbol. We study a pseudodifferential operator with transversal intersections of bicharacteristics, where the principal symbol has double multiplicity, $p=dp=0$, in a small neigborhood $Ω$. Because of this fact, we instead study the subprincipal symbol b, and we can conclude that we get transport equations depending on b where sign changes for the imaginary part of b give approximative solutions with small support. These modes are used to estimate spectral instability, or the pseudospectrum. We also investigate the possibility that we can factorize the model operator as $P(h)=h^2P_1P_2,$ in this way actually annihilating the subprincipal symbol, thus there is no condition for the imaginary part of b. In a follow-up article, we examine different cases for more complex operators with tangential intersections of bicharacteristics, thereby generalizing the findings here.

AI.tldr: Study of semiclassical quasimodes for pseudodifferential operators with transversal intersections of bicharacteristics, focusing on subprincipal symbol's role in transport equations and spectral instability.
AI.motivation: To understand approximative solutions to pseudodifferential equations when principal symbol has double multiplicity (p=dp=0), necessitating analysis of subprincipal symbol instead.
AI.method: Analyze semiclassical quasimodes u(h,b) for operators with transversal bicharacteristic intersections. Study transport equations depending on subprincipal symbol b, examine sign changes in imaginary part of b, and explore factorization P(h)=h²P₁P₂ to eliminate subprincipal symbol.
AI.result: Transport equations depend on subprincipal symbol b; sign changes in imaginary part of b yield approximative solutions with small support. Factorization P(h)=h²P₁P₂ annihilates subprincipal symbol, removing conditions on imaginary part of b.
AI.conclusion: Subprincipal symbol plays crucial role in quasimode construction when principal symbol has double multiplicity. These quasimodes can estimate spectral instability/pseudospectrum. Future work extends to tangential intersections of bicharacteristics.

title: Morse index of min-max stationary integral varifolds
summary: We prove an upper bound for the Morse index of min-max stationary integral varifolds realizing the $d$-dimensional $p$-width of a closed Riemannian manifold.

AI.tldr: Upper bound for Morse index of min-max stationary integral varifolds realizing p-widths in Riemannian manifolds
AI.motivation: Understanding the geometric properties of min-max stationary integral varifolds that realize p-widths, particularly their stability properties as measured by Morse index
AI.method: Mathematical proof establishing an upper bound relationship between the Morse index and the dimension parameter p for these geometric objects
AI.result: Proved an upper bound for the Morse index of min-max stationary integral varifolds that realize the d-dimensional p-width
AI.conclusion: The Morse index of these geometric objects is bounded above, providing important information about their stability and geometric properties in relation to p-width theory
